subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 08_Annexure.indd 233

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: T-Test for Agility (Fitness Test Procedure)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Start/finish line

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The T-Test measures agility, speed, and body control, which are important for sports and overall fitness.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Four cones or markers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Astopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e A flat surface (like a gym floor or open field)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SET-UP 1. Place the cones in a T-shape as follows: * Cone A (starting point) * Cone B (10 meters straight ahead of A) * Cone C (5 meters to the left of B) « Cone D (5 meters to the right of B)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 08_Annexure.indd 234

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Start at Cone A in a ready position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Sprint forward to Cone B and touch it with your right hand. 3. Side-shuffle left to Cone C and touch it with your left hand. 4

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Side-shuffle right to Cone D and touch it with your right hand.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Side-shuffle back to Cone B and touch it again. 6. Run backward to Cone A as fast as possible. 7. Stop the timer when the participant crosses Cone A.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SCORING ¢ Record the time (in seconds) taken to complete the test. e Faster times indicate better agility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep feet parallel during side shuffles.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Ensure proper hand touches at each cone. ¢ Perform 3 trials and take the best time.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Cardiovascular Endurance METER RUN/WALK TEST

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The 600- metre Run/Walk Test measures cardiovascular endurance and assesses how wella person can sustain moderate to high-intensity activity over a short distance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Measuring tape (if the track is not pre-marked)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Flat running surface (track or open field)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Cones or markers (to indicate start and finish points)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Warm-up: Perform 5-10 minutes of light jogging and stretching.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Starting Position: Stand behind the start line in a ready position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Go! Start running or walking as fast as possible when the instructor gives the signal.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Maintain a steady pace and try to complete the 600 meters without stopping.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Finish Line: Stop the timer as soon as the participant crosses the finish line.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 6. Record the total time taken to complete the 600 meters.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SCORING

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The time is recorded in minutes and seconds.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Faster times indicate better endurance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Compare improvement over time instead of using fixed benchmarks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Encourage steady pacing—don’t sprint too fast at the start.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Use the same track and conditions for retests to ensure consistency.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3-Minute Step Test

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Suggested Session Plans for Teachers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 08_Annexure.indd 236

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The 3-Minute Step Test measures cardiovascular endurance by evaluating how quickly the heart recovers after exercise. EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e A 12-inch (30 cm) step or bench

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Metronome or music with a 96 beats-per-minute (bpm) rhythm

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Heart rate monitor (optional) or manual pulse counting

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Warm-up: Perform light stretching and jogging for 5 minutes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Step Pattern e Step up with one foot. ¢ Step up with the other foot. ¢ Step down with one foot. * Step down with the other foot. ¢ Maintain a steady up-up-down-down rhythm. 3. Step to the Beat ¢ The pace should be 96 steps per minute (24 complete steps per minute). * Continue stepping for 3 minutes without stopping. 4. After 3 Minutes ¢ Sit down immediately. ¢ Wait 5 seconds, then measure your pulse for 1 full minute.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Count beats at the wrist (radial artery) or neck (carotid artery).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Record your heart rate (beats per minute).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 236 Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SCORING ¢ Lower heart rates indicate better cardiovascular fitness. ¢ Compare results with previous tests to track improvement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Use a consistent stepping speed.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ No extra movements—keep the upper body relaxed. e Use the same step height for all tests.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Ensure proper posture and breathing throughout.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Strength & Muscular Endurance PusH-UPs TEST (MAXIMUM REPS IN 1 MINUTE) PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Push-Up Test measures upper body strength and endurance, focusing on the chest, shoulders, and triceps.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Flat surface (gym floor or mat for comfort)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Partner or instructor to count reps and check form

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Starting Position ¢ Place hands shoulder-width apart on the floor. ¢ Keep your body straight from head to heels. ¢ Feet should be together or slightly apart.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Performing the Push-Up

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Lower your chest until it’s about 90 degrees at the elbows or until it nearly touches the ground.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Suggested Session Plans for Teachers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 08_Annexure.indd 238

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Push back up to full arm extension.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep a steady pace—no stopping! 3. Counting Reps

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Only correct form counts.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Ifthe body sags or hips rise too much, that rep does not count.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Test Duration ¢ Perform as many push-ups as possible in 1 minute.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SCORING * Record the total number of correct push-ups. ¢ Compare results over time to track improvement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY * No faulty movements—only full push-ups count! ¢ Keep body straight (avoid sagging or bending knees). * Use the same testing method for all students (standard push-up or modified knee push-up for those who need it).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SQuaAT TEST (MAXIMUM REPS IN 1 MINUTE)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Squat Test measures lower body strength and endurance, targeting the quadriceps, hamstrings, glutes, and core. EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Flat surface (gym floor or mat for comfort)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Partner or instructor to count reps and check form

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE 1. Starting Position * Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 238 Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep your chest up and back straight.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Hands can be on hips or extended forward for balance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Performing the Squat

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Lower your body until thighs are parallel to the ground (90-degree angle at knees).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep knees aligned with toes (avoid knees collapsing inward).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Push back up to the starting position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain a steady rhythm—no pausing! 3. Counting Reps

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Only correct squats count.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ If depth is too shallow or form is incorrect, the rep does not count.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Test Duration ¢ Perform as many squats as possible in 1 minute.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SCORING e Record the total number of correct squats. ¢ Compare results over time to track improvement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Keep heels on the ground—no tiptoeing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ No bouncing or half-squats—thighs must reach parallel. e Use the same testing conditions for consistent results.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Suggested Session Plans for Teachers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 08_Annexure.indd 240

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PLANK HOLD TEST (MAXIMUM TIME)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Plank Hold Test measures core strength and endurance, engaging the abdominal muscles, lower back, shoulders, and legs.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Flat surface (gym floor or mat for comfort)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Partner or instructor to track time and check form

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE 1. Starting Position * Get into a forearm plank position: ¢ Elbows directly under shoulders. e Arms bent at 90 degrees. ¢ Keep your body straight from head to heels. ¢ Feet should be hip-width apart. 2. Performing the Plank ¢ Hold the plank position for as long as possible.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain proper form—no sagging hips or raised buttocks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Breathe normally throughout.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. ENDING THE TEST

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The test ends when the participant can no longer hold proper form or chooses to stop.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Record the total time held (in seconds or minutes).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SCORING ¢ Record the longest time the plank is held. ¢ Compare results over time to track improvement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep the body ina straight line—no arching or drooping. e Ensure elbows remain under shoulders for balance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Usethesame testing conditions each time for consistency.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Flexibility SIT-AND-REACH TEST (FLEXIBILITY MEASUREMENT)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Sit-and-Reach Test measures hamstring and lower back flexibility. Good flexibility in these areas helps with posture, injury prevention, and overall mobility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e §it-and-reach box (or a ruler/tape measure placed on the floor)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Flat, non-slippery surface ¢ Partner or instructor to measure the reach

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Suggested Session Plans for Teachers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE 1. Starting Position

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Sit on the floor with legs fully extended and feet flat against the box (or with heels 12 inches apart if using a ruler).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep knees straight and feet flexed (toes pointing upward).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Performing the Test ¢ Reach forward slowly and steadily with both hands.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep hands one on top of the other and palms facing downward. ¢ Hold the stretch for at least 2 seconds at the farthest point. * No bouncing or jerky movements—it must be a smooth reach. 3. Measuring the Reach

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Measure the distance from the starting point (toes = 0 inches) to the farthest reach.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Ifthe fingertips do not reach the toes, record a negative score (e.g., -3 inches).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ If the fingertips go beyond the toes, record a positive score (e.g., +4 inches).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Best of Three Attempts ¢ Perform three trials and record the best score.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY ¢ No bending knees—they must stay straight throughout. e Ensure a smooth reach—no bouncing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Use the same testing method for accurate comparison over time.

text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Speed

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The 50- metre Sprint Test measures speed and acceleration, assessing how quickly a person can cover a short distance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: EQUIPMENT NEEDED

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Flat, non-slippery running surface (track or field) e Measuring tape (to mark 50 meters)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Cones or markers (for start and finish lines)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Partner or instructor to time the sprint

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Warm-Up: Perform dynamic stretching and light jogging for 5-10 minutes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Starting Position

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Stand behind the starting line in a ready sprint stance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ One foot should be slightly in front of the other.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Arms bentat 90 degrees and body leaning slightly forward. 3. Sprint Execution

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Run as fast as possible from start to finish.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain good sprinting form (knees high, arms

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: pumping).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Timing the Sprint

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch starts when the runner begins moving.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Stopwatch stops when the runner crosses the finish line. 5. Recording the Time

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Record the best time from two trials (allowing enough rest between attempts).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GUIDELINES FOR ACCURACY e Ensure a standing start (no rolling starts).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Suggested Session Plans for Teachers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 08_Annexure.indd 244

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Use the same timing method for all students. e Run in proper footwear to avoid slipping.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Stork Balance Test DEFINITION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A test to measure static balance by timing how long a person can maintain a one-legged stance on the ball of the foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PURPOSE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To assess postural stability, balance control, and lower limb strength. SET-UP

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stopwatch

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Flat, non-slip surface

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Barefoot or flat footwear

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Hands on hips throughout the test

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PROCEDURE e Stand barefoot with hands on hips. e Lift one leg and place the toes against the inside of the opposite knee. ¢ Raise the heel of the supporting foot to stand on the ball of the foot. e Start timing once the heel is lifted. e Stop the timer if: — Hands come off hips - Supporting foot moves -— Raised foot touches the ground - Heel drops to the ground — Repeat up to 3 times per leg and take the best time.

text: 0_Prelims.indd 3

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The National Education Policy 2020 envisages a system of education in the country that is rooted in Indian ethos and its civilisational accomplishments in all domains ofhuman endeavour and knowledge, while at the same time preparing students to constructively engage with the prospects and challenges of the twenty-first century. The basis for this aspirational vision has been well laid out by the National Curriculum Framework for School Education (NCF-SE) 2023 across curricular areas at all stages. Having nurtured students’ inherent abilities, touching upon all the five planes of human existence, the pafichakoSas in the Foundational and the Preparatory Stages have paved the way for the progression of their learning further at the Middle Stage. Thus, the Middle Stage acts as a bridge between the Preparatory and the Secondary Stages, spanning three years from Grade 6 to Grade 8.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The NCF-SE 2023, at the Middle Stage, aims to equip students with the skills that are needed to grow as they advance in lives. It endeavours to enhance their analytical, descriptive, and narrative capabilities, and to prepare them for the challenges and opportunities that await them. A diverse curriculum, covering nine subjects in three languages—including at least two languages native to India— Science, Mathematics, Social Sciences, Art Education, Physical Education and Well-being, and Vocational Education promotes their holistic development.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Such a transformative learning culture requires certain essential conditions. One of them is to have appropriate textbooks in different curricular areas as these textbooks will play a central role in mediating between content and pedagogy—a role that will strike a judicious balance between direct instruction and opportunities for exploration and inquiry. Among the other conditions, classroom arrangement and teacher preparation are crucial to establish conceptual connections both within and across curricular areas.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 0_Prelims.indd 4

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The National Council of Educational Research and Training, on its part, is committed in providing students with such high-quality textbooks. Various Curricular Area Groups, which have been constituted for this purpose, comprising notable subject-experts, pedagogues, and practising teachers as their members, have made all possible efforts to develop such textbooks. The book for Physical education and well- being, titled Khel Yatra for Grade 8, is meticulously designed to develop motor skills and engage children in the team sports of Athletics, Table Tennis and Volleyball. Age-specific aspects of Yoga are designed to lay the foundation for healthy living. The textbook aligns with the competencies included in the NCF-SE 2023 for this stage.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra emphasises the importance of physical activity and the values and dispositions essential for life. It incorporates cross-cutting themes, such as inclusion, gender equality, and cultural rootedness.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The content and activities are designed to encourage peer group learning, and enrich the educational experience for both students and teachers. While this textbook is valuable, children should also explore interesting local games and play with friends. This book is not only useful for school learning, but is a valuable resource for parents and community.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: However, in addition to this textbook, students at this stage should also be encouraged to explore various other learning resources. Schoollibraries play a crucial role in making such resources available. Besides, the role of parents and teachers will also be invaluable in guiding and encouraging students to do so.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: With this, I express my gratitude to all those who have been involved in the development of this textbook, and hope that it will meet the expectations of all stakeholders. At the same time, I also invite suggestions and feedback from all its users for further

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: improvement in the coming years. DinesH PRASAD SAKLANI Director

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 0_Prelims.indd 5

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The National Curriculum Framework for School Education 2023 (NCF-SE 2023) recognises the criticality of the health and wellbeing of individuals as a key factor for success in all aspects of life. Considering the focus on holistic well-being, NCF-SE has mandated Physical Education and Well-being as a core curricular area for all stages of school education. To help the teachers and students achieve curricular goals of Physical Education and Well-being, for the first time a textbook has been designed for Grade 8. This book enables students to experience the joy of playing, explore diverse physical activities, practice fitness skills, learn basic sports skills, and immerse in the world of yoga. Sports and physical activities teach important motor skills, socio-emotional awareness and regulation, associated cognitive abilities, as well as the values of self-discipline, hard work, teamwork, and a gracious acceptance of one’s strengths and vulnerabilities.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To achieve the goals of fitness, sports and holistic well-being, the Grade 8 textbook is designed to have the following six units.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Foundations of Physical Education and Well-being

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Physical and Motor Fitness

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Fundamental Skills of Athletics

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Fundamental Skills of Table Tennis

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Fundamental Skills of Volleyball

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 6. Yoga

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In Unit 1, students explore the connection between physical education (PE) and well-being, emphasising its impact on personal and social

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: behaviour. Through playing games and engaging in discussions, students will understand the importance of living a healthy lifestyle;

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 0_Prelims.indd 6

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: concepts of Physics and Biology ina playful manner, and how physical activity adds to their overall enjoyment and success. Students will also learn about the safety measures to minimise the risk of injuries and create a healthy environment for the students.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In Unit 2, students learn different fitness components like endurance, strength, flexibility, and balance. The main aim is to understand how each of these components contributes to overall health.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Units 3, 4 and 5 focus on learning new games. Athletics is introduced in Unit 3, Table Tennis in Unit 4 and Volleyball in Unit 5. Through interactive sessions and group exercises, students will discover the excitement of sports and health advantages of physical activities. The emphasis will be on inclusivity, team cohesion, and enjoyment of movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In the last unit, that is, Unit 6 students immerse in the holistic nature of yoga. They learn about Yama (social discipline) and Niyama (Personal discipline) to inculcate healthy habits for positive behavior. Systematic practice of various yogdsanas starting with Sukshma Vydyama (loosening exercises), preparatory breathing practices and step-by-step performance of each dsana helps our body to be flexible, strong, balanced and disease free. Various techniques of Pranayama strengthen the lungs, improve functioning of major systems of our body, calm down the mind, improve concentration and help in achieving overall harmony and well-being. To explore the world within us and experience deep sense of peace, tranquility and bliss, students learn different techniques of Dharana (single pointed concentration) and Dhydna (meditation). Learning various yogic practices lays the foundation for a long and healthy life.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this book, apart from learning the games and physical activities, students will learn to follow rules, understand the importance of safe practices and fair play, work harmoniously in groups, treat each other with courtesy and respect, as well as, help each other, and experience the joy of playing together. Inculcation of these values and dispositions will partly happen while children are engaged in the physical activities or games and partly, they will be reinforced

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Structure and Flow of Classes

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Refer to the previous class’ textbook for suggestive session plan. As per NCF-SE 2023 recommendations 90 hours are allocated to physical education and well-being. So, 115-120 periods of 40 minutes each for activities and classes along with 15-20 periods for formative and summative assessment have been allocated. Principals and physical education teachers have the liberty to plan classes keeping in mind equal emphasis and distribution of all units. Since assessment depicting progression in the motor fitness, sport-specific skills, yoga and psychosocial domain, session-ending assessment procedure will remain the same as formative assessment. Suggestive timetable assumes at least 5 periods of 40 minute each, per week. NCF-SE recommends allocating block period (2 periods together) for physical education and well-being. If it is not possible to allocate two block periods and one single period every week, it is necessary to design single periods with different focus to ensure sufficient time for activities, game and circle time.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: For joyful experience, safety of children and effective development

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: of competencies, teachers may follow the instructions given below:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure adequate play area and that there are no obstructions in the play area.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: For group activities, mark the area into smaller blocks to prevent students from running into each other.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: While dividing the teams, make sure that the divison is fair and balanced in terms of bodyweight, height and skills required for the activity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that a first aid kit is available and accessible.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that students are treated with respect and they feel emotionally and socially safe.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Provide regular encouragement and support to all the students.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure students have access to fair redressal of grievances during the Physical Education period.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Encourage students to be aware of their surroundings while playing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Instruct the students not to aim at the opponent.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Encourage the students to be careful while pushing or pulling the opponent in the activity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that students do proper warm-up and cool-down exercises. Encourage them to create their own routines.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Provide opportunities to students for interactions before, during and after the class.

text: Introduce sports skills gradually. Complexity can be increased by playing mini versions of the sport gradually building individual capacities such as, observation, reflection, emotional regulation, expanding spatial awareness and peripheral vision, and making quick judgements based on gameplay.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Discuss social capacities such as, effective communication, collective decision making, and working together towards a common goal, during circle time and at relevant moments in the sport.

text: Discuss the concepts of Physics such as, conduction, motion,

text: etc. and concepts of Biology such as breathing, muscles, neuro

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: muscular coordination, muscle adaptation in a playful manner through physical activities.

text: Encourage students to take more responsibility for building a

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: culture of inclusive sports at school. Help them to play an active

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: role in ensuring all students feel safe, motivated, and encouraged

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 01_Warm Up.indd 1

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Watim=up

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Sideways Hopping

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Jump from side to side over a line or a cone with both feet together engaging the core and lower body. This will enhance explosive strength and neuromuscular co-ordination.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lateral Shuffle

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lateral shuffle is a fast footwork drill done on an agility ladder. Step in with one foot, then the other, and step out laterally, repeati a shuffle pattern.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This improves coordination, speed, and sense of rhythm.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Skiers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: With feet together, jump from side to side as if skiing, keeping knees slightly

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: bent. This targets lower body explosiveness and cardiovascular endurance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. High Knee Jump with Object

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. Hold a small object in front of the chest using both hands as shown in the figure. Begin performing high knees, lifting each knee toward the chest. Aim to tap both knees to the object alternatively. This engages the core muscles. Avoid leaning back or swinging the torso.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Seated Ball Toss with Partner

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Start with both partners seated facing each other with their

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: knees bent in front. The first _ partner holds a ball with both hands and tosses it over to the second partner. The second partner catches the ball and

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: throws it back to the first partner. They perform alternate tosses.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 6. Progressive Vertical Reach Jumps

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart, arms relaxed and knees bent with hips in a mid-squat position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: as high as possible. Land softly on the toes and immediately

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: perform the next jump. This helps in

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: the development of explosive strength.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 01_Warm Up.indd 2

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 7. Shuttle Run

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A shuttle run is a drill in which a person runs to a point, touches or reaches an object, and then returns. This improves cardiovascular fitness, agility, and reaction time.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 8. Twist with Ball

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In a seated V-position as shown in the figure below, hold a weighted ball and twist the torso to tap the ball on each side. This strengthens abdominal muscles and enhances rotational core stability.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 9. Figure-8 Waist Mobility Drill

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Move a ball or an object in a figure-8 pattern around the waist. This promotes dynamic mobility in the trunk and improves flexibility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up and Cool-down

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 10. Scapular Retraction Stand and squeeze the shoulder blades together without lifting the shoulders with the use of resistance, such as resistance bands or towels as show in the figure. This strengthens the upper back muscles.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 11. Passing the Ball Between the Knees

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Stand and pass a ball around and between the knees in

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: a controlled pattern. This improves coordination,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: core engagement, and hip mobility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 12. Star with Cloth

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Place a cloth or a marker at each point of an imaginary star on the floor. Step or reach at each point using legs or hands. This enhances balance, and motor control.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 01_Warm Up.indd 4

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Neck Exercise with a Cloth

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Use a cloth for gentle resistance around the head and perform slow neck movements in various directions. This strengthens the neck muscles.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Resistive Wrist Exercises

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Use a band or an object to perform wrist flexion and extensions along with radial or ulna deviation against resistance (as shown in the figure). This helps to develop forearm and wrist strength.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Perturbation

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This is a partner activity in which a Partner B will stand behind a Partner A, as shown in the figure. Partner B will apply an external force such as a gentle push (a rough push may result in injury) in all the directions, in a step-by- step manner. Partner A will try to hold their position. This enhances proprioception (sense of joint), neuromuscular control and balance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: [ 5 This unit explores the link between physical activity and personal growth, integrating fitness, mental resilience, teamwork, and safety awareness with foundational concepts from physics and biology. Through engaging activities, students will learn how principles like balance, force, motion, and gravity affect their movements, while understanding how muscles, bones, respiration, and circulation support physical performance. They will build motivation, courage, and discipline by tackling physical challenges, tracking their progress, and committing to self-improvement. Additionally, students willbe guided to recognise and report bullying, mental health concerns, and inappropriate behavior, fostering a safe,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

text: The Motion-in-Action Relay is to help students understand and experience linear motion, rotational motion, and projectile motion through a relay-style activity. Students will measure time (for linear and rotational motion) and distance (for projectile motion) in both SI (International System of Units—metres, seconds) and CGS units (centimetres, gram- seconds).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ SI Unit: Distance in metres (m). ¢ CGS Unit: Distance in centimetres (cm).

text: ¢ Divide the students into teams of 4-5 members each. ¢ Set up three activity zones representing different levels of intensity: — Zone 1: Low Intensity (walking in place, slow jogging). — Zone 2: Medium Intensity (moderate jumping jacks, fast jogging). — Zone 3: High Intensity (sprinting or burpees).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Part 1: Baseline Measurement — Before starting, students sit quietly for 1 minute. — Each student measures their resting breathing rate and pulse rate in the following way -— ¢ For calculating breathing rate- Count breaths for 60 seconds. ¢ For calculating pulse rate—Count heartbeat for 60 seconds.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Finally, record the data in a chart.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Part 2: Physical Challenge — Zone 1 (Low Intensity) ¢ Students walk in place or jog lightly for 2 minutes. ¢ Afterwards, they measure and record their breathing and pulse rates. — Zone 2 (Medium Intensity) ¢ Students perform moderate jumping jacks or fast jogging for 1 minute. ¢ Then, they record breathing and pulse rates. — Zone 3 (High Intensity) e Students sprint for 30 metres or do burpees for 30 seconds. ¢ Immediately after, they measure and record their breathing and pulse rates.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Part 3: Recovery Observation — After completing all zones, students sit quietly for 3 minutes. — They measure their pulse rates every 30 seconds to monitor recovery. — Record recovery time for all participants.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Teams track how quickly breathing and pulse rates return to baseline after Zone 3.

text: To begin, a large circle is made using cones and divided into two areas: the ‘playing zone’ and the ‘exercise zone’, with a cone placed in the exercise zone labeled ‘exercise.’

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Athletics

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: c b Athletics is one of the oldest and most basic forms of sport. It is also

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: known as Track and Field and the events of athletics are classified as

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Track Events, Field Events, and Combined Events. The fundamental skills of

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: athletics are divided into different categories, including running, jumping,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: and throwing events. Athletics is a multi-physical skill training discipline

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: that emphasises improving physical traits like strength, speed, endurance,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: agility, flexibility, and coordination. It comprises a wide range of events, including long-distance running, jumping, throwing, and sprinting.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Athletics have a positive impact on human development throughout the physical training phase of education. The appropriate operation and physical development of the human body is assured by carefully chosen activities and their application in all age groups and physical education fields. Running, jumping, throwing, and walking all contribute to

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: the growth and development of the physiological system as well as fundamental physical and technical skills.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 04_Unit 3.indd 58

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Furthermore, athletics is a way to develop character and willpower during training and competition. Physical education teachers may assist in development characteristics like willpower, determination, resoluteness, self-discipline, team spirit, and awareness to succeed by observing how athletes behave throughout practice and competition.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Running

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Running is a method of terrestrial locomotion by which humans and other animals move quickly on foot. Running is an aerial gait in which the feet are above the ground. Running is one of the most essential athletic skills, requiring proper technique, speed, endurance, and coordination.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: TECHNIQUES TO START THE RACE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: There are two types of starts:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Crouch start or Sitting start: This is used for all running events up to 400-metre. It allows the runner to react to the sound and start the race as fast as possible by properly positioning their centre of gravity in the ‘set’ position. In a short-distance race, the outcome is decided by a quick start and an increased acceleration capacity. Modern starting techniques use three different types of starting positions, which are outlined below:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: (a) Bunch or Bullet start (b) Medium start (c) Elongated start

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Standing start: This type of start is commonly used in middle- distance and long-distance races. The athlete begins in an upright position, with one foot slightly ahead of the other, and starts running smoothly when the race begins. This start allows for better pacing and control over longer distances. In this Grade you will only learn about Crouch or Sitting Start.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. ON YouR MARKS POSITION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ On the command “On your marks”, the runners assume the position for the crouch start.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ They take a position directly in front of the starting blocks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The foot of the stronger leg is placed on the front block and the foot of the other leg on the rear block.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Care should be taken that only the tip of the foot touches the ground and that the rear foot is pressed firmly against the block.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The knee of the rear leg is now placed on the ground. Both hands (shoulder width apart) contact the ground with the thumbs.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e The thumb and the index finger are spread so that they form a high bridge.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Head carriage is relaxed, and the eyes are focused on a point on the ground.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Teachers should

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Ensure that the blocks are appropriately set up for the runner.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Observe the runner’s posture including the head position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Check that the hand position is comfortable and correctly placed.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 04_Unit 3.indd 60

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Acceleration >

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. SET POSITION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e At “set”, the runners raise their hips by lifting the knee of the rear leg off the ground.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The body weight is distributed almost evenly over the four supporting areas.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The head remains in a natural, relaxed position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The ‘set’ position conveys to the runner’s body the preliminary tension necessary for a powerful start from the blocks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Inorder to achieve a high initial speed, the angles of both legs are of particular importance. An angle of about 90° at the front knee and of about 110° to 130° at the rear knee is appropriate.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Teachers should ¢ Observe from the front and side.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Observe the position of the trunk and the limbs.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢« Ensure that runners are stable.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Confirm that the runner’s focus is on sprinting from the blocks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Athletics

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: DRIVE PHASE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: At “go”, the sprinter starts without any delay. A quick response to the gun is of major importance for a fast start.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The power exerted on the blocks when starting will transmit the highest possible initial velocity to the runner’s body.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This is brought about by an explosive pushing of both

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: legs against the blocks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The main technical skills in the leg action are:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — After coming off the rear starting block, the push-off leg starts to drive forward, that is, the thigh is rapidly drawn forward and upward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — The leading leg should remain in an approximately horizontal position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Proper arm action:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — The arms have an important function in helping to produce the starting acceleration.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — Pay special attention to the action of the arms.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — The movement of the swinging leg requires that the respective arm swings forward and upward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — The arm tends to bend increasingly at the elbow until it reaches an angle of about 90° in the final phase of the movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 04_Unit 3.indd 62

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Teachers should

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Observe the speed of reaction to the gun and the sequence of movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Observe the speed and extension of the knee and hip joints. e Ensure that the athlete optimises the drive from the blocks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Observe that the arms move quickly so that there is a coordinated leg balance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — Inthis process, at the first swing towards the forehead, the elbow has a slight outward spread.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — The opposite arm performs a corresponding counter- movement backwards.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. ACCELERATION PHASE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e At the beginning of the acceleration phase, the runner has a marked forward body lean.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e With an increasing rate and length of stride, the angle of inclination gradually decreases, so that after 20m the runner reaches the normal sprinting position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The forward body lean should be at its maximum when the front foot comes off the starting block and during the initial strides.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ A good body lean is a function of the power exerted by the push-off force during the first few strides.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The greater this force, the smaller the angle between the runner’s body and the ground.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Runners with a poor push-off force will come to an upright position sooner.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In some cases, runners with a good push-off force prematurely assume an upright position because they raise their heads immediately after the start in order to look up to the finish.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Athletics

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Upon the command “on your marks”. The body weight is either distributed over both legs or is already over the front leg.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Upon the command “set”, the flexion of the front knee is in most cases increased and in all runners, the body weight is now over the front leg.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The upper body is bent forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: If the time lag between the commands “set” and “go” is long, it will result in the danger of a false start due to a further forward shift of the body’s centre of gravity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 04_Unit 3.indd 64

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Teachers should

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Observe the action of the limbs and position of the trunk and head.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Observe the increase in stride length and frequency.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that the runner’s transition into the sprinting action is smooth.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: FINISH PHASE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The runner maintains top speed through the finish line.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The runner leans forward slightly to break the finish line faster.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e The runner uses proper arm drive and stride control to sustain momentum. ¢ The runner avoids decelerating too soon to ensure the best possible time. ¢ The following techniques can be used to attain optimal finishing position - Run Through: This technique involves maintaining full speed beyond the finish line to ensure the best possible race time.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — Lunge: In a close race, an athlete may extend one leg forward and lean their upper body towards the finish line to break the tape first.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: — Shoulder Shrug: Moving one shoulder forward at the finish line can help an athlete gain an advantage in a very close race by crossing the line first.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Jumping

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Jumping is an essential skill in athletics, defined as the act of propelling oneself into the air using one or both legs. It requires power, coordination, and technique. From a technical perspective, jumping events vary in complexity, ranging from the simple Long Jump to the High Jump and Triple Jump, with the Pole Vault appearing more intricate. The primary objective in these events is to achieve the greatest possible height or distance. In the Triple Jump, athletes aim to maximise the total distance of three successive jumps, while in the Pole Vault, they utilise a pole to assist in clearing greater heights. The key components of jumping are:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Approach run ¢« Acontrolled run to generate momentum. e Athletes must maintain speed and balance before take- off. 2. Take-off ¢ The athlete pushes off from the ground using one or both legs. e Proper body alignment is essential for maximising height and distance. 3. Flight phase ¢ The body remains in motion after take-off. e Proper posture and leg movement are crucial to maintaining balance. 4. Landing e Athletes should land with bent knees to absorb impact. ¢ Athletes should maintain a balanced position to avoid fouls.

text: Long Jump Strategy

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The long jump is divided into the following phases- approach, take-off, flight, and landing. 1. APPROACH PHASE e Approach length varies from 10 strides for beginners to over 20 strides for elite jumpers. e The running technique is similar to sprinting, with speed gradually increasing until take-off. e The jumper accelerates to its maximum controllable speed.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintaining a consistent stride pattern is crucial for an optimal take-off position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FLIGHT PHASE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The jumper prepares for landing while maintaining balance and control in the air.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Three different techniques can be used: Sail, Hang, and Hitch-Kick.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this, players will be learning only Sail and Hang.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Sail: The simplest technique, where the jumper extends their legs forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The free leg is maintained in the take-off position. The trunk stays upright and vertical. The take-off leg trails for most of the flight.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Near the end of the flight, the take-off leg bends and moves forwards and upwards.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Both legs extend forward for landing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Hang: The jumper stretches arms and legs backwards before bringing them forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The free leg lowers through hip joint rotation. The hips are pushed forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The take-off leg aligns parallel to the free leg. The arms are positioned upward and backward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Athletics

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ideal technique especially for jumpers in the 6-7 metres range

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. LANDING PHASE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The legs are nearly fully extended.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The trunk leans forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The arms are pulled backward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The hips are pushed forward towards the touchdown point.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The jumper strives to maximise the distance of the flight path.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Landing with the feet first while avoiding backward movement prevents distance loss.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Proper body positioning minimises impact and enables a smooth transition after landing.

text: An obstacle course is set up around a square area, with a designated group of Hunters whose goal is to capture other athletes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The aim of the Hunters is to remove all athletes from the square simultaneously to win.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: If at least one athlete remains in the square by the end of all rounds, the non-Hunters win.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The game is played in limited rounds to prevent fatigue. Anew team of Hunters is assigned at the start of each round to ensure fairness and rotation.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The jumper uses one of the two main techniques: Straddle or Fosbury Flop.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: We will discuss only Straddle in this class: Straddle Technique 1. The jumper clears the bar facing downwards.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. The take-off leg extends first over the bar, followed by the trailing leg.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. The body remains parallel to the bar with the head and shoulders leading the clearance. 4. LANDING PHASE ¢ The jumper's head is drawn towards the chest. ¢ Landing is on the shoulders and back. e Knees are apart for touch down.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: G (5 In this unit, we will learn about the game of table tennis, one

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: of the fastest racquet game in the world. Played on a wooden table with a dark, matte surface divided by a net, this fast-paced sport uses a 40+mm ball and a racquet of any shape or size. Players use a combination of forehand and backhand strokes, applying both defensive and attacking techniques to win rallies and score points. It requires quick reflexes, as well as eye-hand and sound coordination. Fast movements, accuracy, concentration along with attention attracts people of all ages and genders to this game. Earlier known as Ping-Pong and Gossima, table tennis is a recreational, remedial and competitive sport.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To understand table tennis better we will learn about speed, strength, quick reaction time and its combination, as well as physical, mental,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: social, emotional and spiritual skills which enable players to play, sustain, and live a holistic life.

text: In any racquet sport, including table tennis, Grip is the first and

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A grip is of two types:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. SHAKEHAND GRIP

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 05_Unit 4.indd 94

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Shake the hand with the slant racquet and hold it in the palm.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Place the thumb and index finger parallel to the straight edge of the rubber.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Wrap the remaining three fingers around the handle.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Ensure that the grip is loose as this will give more readiness, flexibility and strength for better rotation and stability.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. PENHOLD GRIP

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Hold the racquet as you are holding a pen.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Thumb and index finger should hold the actual handle near the blade.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The remaining fingers are positioned around the back of the racquet blade.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Note: There are two types of Penhold Grip; Chinese Grip and Japnese Grip but nowadays, the Shakehand Grip is more commonly used worldwide.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Footwork is one of the most important aspects of table tennis, in order to return a ball at marked 1.525 m wide endline and its imaginary extention on both sides. The key principle of an efficient return is returning the ball in front of the body’s medial line in the backhand grip and comfortable lateral movement in the forehand grip. Also, a quick and proper placement of the foot, sideways, backwards and forwards with a balanced weight, is necessary while returning to make it comfortable. Footwork helps players move efficiently to position themselves for the best possible execution of skills. Proper footwork allows for quick reactions, better balance, and smoother transitions between strokes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Basic Footwork comprises the following:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. STANCE ¢ Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. ¢ Keep knees slightly bent and body leaning forwards. e Stay on the balls of your feet to enable quick movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. SIDE-TO-SIDE MOVEMENT ¢ Push off with one foot to move laterally. ¢ Maintain balance while gliding smoothly. ¢ Keep the racquet in a neutral position, ready for the next stroke. 3. FORWARD MOVEMENT ¢ Step forward with the leading foot when attacking. ¢ Transfer your weight onto the front foot. ¢ Stay low to maintain stability.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. BACKWARD MOVEMENT ¢ Push off the front foot to move backward. ¢ Keep the body centered and balanced. ¢ Stay ready to return to the table quickly. 5. FOLLOW-THROUGH e After each shot, return to ready stance. ¢ Stay light on your feet to adjust for the next movement.

text: In table tennis most of the players score a point within the first 40 to 50 seconds and the major cause is the effectiveness of the service. text: A Basic Service comprises the following:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity | Players will participate in pairs. Each player takes turns serving with a topspin motion, aiming to land the ball on the opponent’s side consistently. If a service bounces twice or forces the opponent into a weak return, then the service is considered successful, and the player earns one point. If the serve goes out or into the net, the service is unsuccessful, and the opponent earns the point. The first player to reach five points wins the round, while the loser switches to challenge a different opponent.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To increase the difficulty, the ‘target accuracy challenge’ can be introduced, where specific areas on the table are marked, and players earn extra points for landing their service in those zones. Another variation is the ‘spin challenge’, where players must apply more spin with each service, making it harder for their opponent to return the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Notes for the teacher

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The teachers should first demonstrate the correct topspin service technique, highlighting grip, body position, and the brushing motion needed to generate spin. Player should practice the service against a wall or with partners, receiving individual feedback on their form.

If the service goes into the net or off the table, it is considered unsuccessful, then the opponent earns the point. The first player to reach five points wins the round, while the loser switches to face a new opponent.

The more the ball spins backwards, the better the service. Another variation is the ‘target zone challenge’, in which players aim to land their backspin service in specific marked areas on the table for extra points.

text: Lead-up Activity ‘|

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Players will compete in pairs. Each player will rally using only the backhand drive, aiming to keep the ball on the table. The rally continues until one player makes a mistake, such as hitting the ball off the table or into the net. The player who wins the rally earns one point, while the losing player switches and faces a new opponent. The first player to reach five points is declared the winner of the round.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Table Tennis

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To increase the difficulty level, different variations can be introduced. In the ‘target challenge’, specific zones on the opponent’s side of the table are marked, and players earn an extra point if they land their drive in those areas. In the timed rally, the goal is to maintain the longest backhand drive rally without making an error, and the player achieving the longest streak is declared the winner. For a more competitive round, a knockout game can be added in which any player who loses three rallies in a row must perform a quick exercise, such as five jumping jacks, before rejoining the game.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Notes for the teacher e Show the correct backhand drive technique, focusing on grip, stance, and follow-through.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Allow players to practice individually, against the wall, or with partners while providing corrective feedback to them.

They aim to land their shots in the marked areas along with the spin on the table for bonus points.

text: Volleyball

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: b G Volleyball is a fast-paced, exciting team sport played by two

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: teams on a rectangular court divided by a net. The objective is

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: to score points by sending the ball over the net in a way that it lands

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: on the opponent's court. Each team consists of six players on the court

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: at a time, with specialised roles such as spikers, setters, blockers, and liberos.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Each team has up to three touches to return the ball over the net and the block touch is not counted. In this unit, we will experience and learn basic skills like serving, passing, setting, spiking, blocking and digging.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Underhand Pass in volleyball, also known as a bump pass, dig pass or simple pass, is a fundamental skill used to receive and control the ball, typically after a serve or an attacking hit (smash or spike) from the opposing team.

text: 1. GRIP AND HAND POSITION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

Ensure the thumbs are parallel, pointing forward and slightly down as shown in the figure. Lock-in the elbows (should not bend), extend the arms in front and bend the wrist downwards.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Underhand Serve is a type of serve in volleyball in which the player strikes the ball with an upwards and forward motion, using an underhand swinging technique to send the ball correctly over the net into the opponent’s court. 1. STANCE e Place the non-dominant foot slightly ahead while keeping the toes pointed forward. Hold the ball in the non-dominant hand, slightly cupped to prevent it from swaying or falling out of the hand, bend your knees and upper body while maintaining the balance. ¢ Move the arm that holds the ball, from the lower side of the body in front of the hitting arm, let the ball reach the height of the upper thigh at the side of the body and in front of the hitting arm. ¢ As the server, move the shoulders towards the ball and shift the hips back, while keeping the upper back straight.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION ¢ Swiftly move the arm in a pendulum-like manner. Next, forcefully swing it forward and use a closed fist to strike the ball’s bottom. ¢ The server’s non-dominant foot should be in front when the server shifts the weight onto it.

text: An Overhead Serve in volleyball is a serve in which the player tosses the ball into the air and strikes it with an overhead arm swing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. STANCE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stand behind the baseline with feet shoulder-width apart and keep one foot in front of the other opposite to the hitting hand.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Toss the ball with your non-dominant hand. The toss should be near vertical and high enough for a full arm swing while the fall of the ball remains as per the desired path.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Step forward with the foot opposite to the serving hand.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Swing the serving arm back, next to the head.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ To bring the dominant hand forward, take the lead with the elbow.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Use the heel or the base of the palm to smash the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Spiking a volleyball entails forcefully striking the ball over the net towards the floor of the opponent’s court. 1. STANCE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Stand with the feet shoulder-width apart for balance. Position yourself under or slightly behind the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Raise the dominant arm, with its elbow bent, slightly behind the head. This results in a powerful angle for the spike. ¢ Monitor the ball continuously to anticipate its fall. ¢ Maintain constant focus on the ball, especially as it approaches the spiking zone. 2. EXECUTION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Extend the non-dominant hand upwards while tilting the torso inline in the falling ball’s path.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Bring the dominant arm down forcefully, making contact with the ball at its highest point.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Aim to spike the ball with your palm.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ To create a spin and a sharp downwards trajectory, spike the ball at the centre or top centre, then lead it downwards with a snapping motion of the wrist.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ While swinging the arm, rotate the torso slightly to generate more power from the core. The power for the spike is generated by the movement of the upper extremities, torso, pelvic and the lower extremities.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Right-handed players step with their left foot first, then their right foot, and finally their left foot for balance and power. Left-handed players reverse the sequence.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: FOLLOW-THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e After making contact, the motion continues with the arm moving downwards and forward. As the movement finishes, the wrist snaps to direct the ball to the opposite side of the court.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ) Aim to use the whole body to serve: The role of potential and

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: kinetic energy. To generate a powerful and effective serve, it is important to use the whole body, applying both types of energy.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Potential Energy is stored in the body when a player bends their knees, loads their arm, and prepares to serve. This energy builds up before the movement. Kinetic Energy is released when the player extends their legs, swings their arm, and makes contact with the ball, converting stored energy into motion for a strong serve.

text: Spiking is also known as smash which can be done from any place of the court but smashing near the net helps more in scoring a point.

text: e Upper Extremities: These include the arms, from the shoulder to the hands.

text: ¢ Lower Extremities: These include the legs, from the hip to the toes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Blocking is a skill which is performed close to the net to intercept the ball spiked from the opponent. It is a defensive move in which defenders try to stop or deflect the ball back to the opponent’s side. A block can be executed either solo or with another blocker.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. STANCE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Standing near the net, with the knees slightly bent and the arms raised, the blocker will be on their toes and ready to move in any direction.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION e Extend the hands over the net to face the opponent, the blocker will rise and reach the ball just in front of the spiker in order to block the ball over the net. * To direct the ball to the opposing team’s court, keep the fingers spread and angle the hands downwards.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW-THROUGH (LANDING)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Tominimise the body’s impact at the time of the landing, keep the knees bent so that the feet absorb the impact and prepare the body for the next move.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity Make multiple players stand in a queue across the net. Every pair will be given a duration of 30 seconds in which they have to jump together and clap each other’s palms above the net. At the same time, they have to keep on moving towards the far-side sideline. After 30 seconds, there will be another blow of the whistle and then the blocker has to stop. Now, new pair will start doing the same. While clapping each other’s hands, if a player touches the net, the clap will not be counted. The pair with the maximum number of claps will be the winner.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Dig is a defensive skill used to prevent the ball from touching the ground after an opponent’s spike or drop near the net. It involves using the forearms or hands to control and redirect the ball upwards, allowing the team to continue the play.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. STANCE ¢ Keep the feet shoulder-width apart, knees bent, and body low.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Weight should be balanced on the balls of the feet for quick movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The arms must be extended and the hands must be kept together, forming a strong platform.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Diggers must bend their knees to stay low towards the ground and position their hands in front for quick reactions.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION ¢ Move quickly to get under the ball. ¢ Keep your arms straight and use the forearm to absorb the impact.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Angle the forearm to direct the ball towards the setter. * Use Both Hands: Whenever possible, a dig should be performed with both hands together, forming a contact point to control the ball’s direction and prevent it from going out of bounds. e Avoid Swinging the Arms: Instead of swinging, absorb the ball’s impact using the legs and a firm forearm.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW-THROUGH * Maintain control and balance after contact. ¢ Incase ofa dive, roll the body to neutralise the impact.

text: Lead-up Activity ¥

text: A feeder stands four feet ahead of a digger, holding one soft sponge ball in each hand. The digger starts in a squat position with hands joined in a ready stance. The feeder randomly drops one of the balls, and the digger must react quickly to reach, get below the ball, and catch it before it hits the ground. Each digger gets 10 attempts, and the player with the most successful catches is the winner of the drill.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: G G Yoga is a journey of self-discovery that balances our body, mind,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: and inner self. This holistic approach nurtures our physical, mental, emotional, intellectual, and spiritual well-being. Furthermore, the practice of yoga strengthens us from within and cultivates determination, inner strength, and courage. In Grade 8, we will explore how yoga helps us find inner peace and gain a deeper understanding of ourselves. We will also explore the philosophical roots of yoga, understanding its ancient wisdom, and how it remains relevant in our modern lives. Let us prepare to embark on this beautiful journey that

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: will transform us into healthy, happy, and peaceful individuals. C C

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 07_Unit 6.indd 168

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: About Yoga

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga is more than just stretching and bending; it is an ancient science that guides us towards a harmonious life. It teaches us how to cultivate a natural balance among the body, mind and emotions. This inner harmony is inspired by nature’s perfect balance, just as it harmonises day and night or the changing seasons. The Bhagavad Gita defines yoga as “samatvam yoga uchyate (2.48)”, meaning “Yoga is a state of balance.”

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The key to achieving this state is to focus on the present moment, and enjoying what is happening right now rather than dwelling on the past or anticipating the future. This practice naturally reduces stress and brings freedom from desires. Furthermore, it helps us mindfully connect with the world while teaching us to be kind, compassionate, and understanding towards others’ feelings. Let us now turn our attention to the yoga practices that further deepen our connection to the present moment.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Do you remember those amazing yoga poses we learnt in Grade 7, like the graceful Marjaridsana and the energising Surya Namaskara? We explored the concept of Pancha Kosha to gain a deeper understanding of the different layers of the self. We even mastered some challenging poses like the Utakatasana, Sarvagasana, Danurdsana, and the Matsydsana. We also learnt to regulate our breath with Bhastrika Pranayama and discovered the benefits of Hasta Mudra. Now, let us continue this fascinating journey by deepening our understanding, and learning a few more practices.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this grade, we will explore how yoga can support us, particularly as we navigate changes and learn to manage our emotions. We will explore Yama and Niyama and learn how to apply them in our daily lives. We will also learn Sukshma Vyayama, Sthula Vyayama, Surya Namaskara, dsana

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: (yoga postures), relaxation techniques, Hasta Mudrdas (hand gestures), Satkarma (cleansing practices), Pranayama (breathing exercises), Pratyahara (learning to control our senses), Dharana (focusing our minds), Dhydna (meditation), and Krida Yoga (yoga games). These practices will help us concentrate, manage distractions, and find inner peace in the present moment.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: eS A . Chapter 1 forDailyLife

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga, with its rich and vast history, has been practised for

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: thousands of years. Over time, various masters documented

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: their techniques and experiences in ancient yoga texts. These texts are more than just books; they are treasure chests holding the profound wisdom of yoga masters. This wisdom passed down through generations, illuminates the path of yoga, offering guidance on ethical living, physical postures, breath regulation, and mental discipline.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Some of the most important yoga texts are as follows:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Patafijali Yoga Sutra: Maharishi Patafijali’s Yoga Sutra is the initial systematic text of yoga sadhana. It has four pada (chapters), and contains 195 short, concise, and powerful statements that guide us on the path of yoga. These sutras teach us various important concepts, such as Ashtanga Yoga. Hatha Pradipika: This text discusses the practical aspects of yoga and is divided into 4 chapters. Swami Svatmarama is the author of this text. It explains how to practise dsanas, Shatkarma (six cleansing techniques), Pranayama, mudra, Bandha (neuromuscular or energy locks—muscle contractions that facilitate energy flow) and Samadhi. Gheranda Samhita: The Gheranda Samhita, written by Rishi Gheranda, is a practical guide to yoga comprising seven chapters. It teaches Saptanga Yoga, a step-by-step method that begins with body exercises and leads to inner understanding. It talks about Shatkarma, dsana, mudra, Pratyahara, Pranayama, Dhyana and Samadhi.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 07_Unit 6.indd_ 172

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The Bhagvad Gita, an ancient scripture, shares deep wisdom about Yoga, with Shri Krishna guiding Arjuna through various paths of yoga across 18 chapters. Similarly, the Yoga Vasistha, a revered text, features Sage VaSistha illuminating Shri Rama on yogic principles for understanding life and finding inner peace. Both these texts, along with Maharishi Patafijali's structured Yoga Sutras and the practical guidance found in the Hatha Pradipika and Gheranda Samhita, offer valuable insights into the core ideas and teachings of yoga from different periods of ancient Indian history. These texts emphasise that yoga is much more than just physical postures; it is a holistic way of living. By understanding and applying their teachings, we can enhance our physical and mental well-being, learn to live with integrity and mindfulness, become better individuals, and contribute positively to society.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Having explored the ancient texts, let us now learn about their practical application through the practice of Yama and Niyama.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: YAMA AND NIYAMA Yama

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: As we all know, Ashtanga Yoga consists of eight limbs, the first of which is Yama. Yamas are universal guidelines for being good that everyone, everywhere, at any time, should try to follow, regardless of their religion or region. Yama’s principles help us become good citizens who care for others. Patafijali's Yoga Sutras explain these disciplines as follows:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: er ceee

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yama consists of five principles: Ahimsa (non-violence), Satya (truthfulness), Asteya (non-stealing), Brahmacharya (moderation), and Aparigraha (non-possessiveness).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: By practising these Yamas, we can create a peaceful and harmonious society where everyone feels valued and respected.
